abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Industrial
            Development Bank Project for Pakistan was marginally
            satisfactory. The project contributed positively to private
            industrial investment, its sustainability is likely with
            certain changes, and both the Bank and Borrower performed
            satisfactorily. However, the institutional objectives were
            only partially achieved due to the extreme ambitions of the
            project. Several lessons can be learned from this project.
            First multi-institutional lending operations allow a broader
            and more effective policy dialogue with GOP and serve as a
            more effective vehicle for broader institutional and
            sectoral objectives. Second, a DFC that continues to
            specialize in a single product operation will find it
            difficult to survive in a more competitive environment.
            Adequate response in product and resource diversification is
            needed to enable it to find its market niche. Third,
            restructuring and rehabilitation of Government controlled
            institutions requires substantial supervision by the Bank,
            strong management, and full support from the Government.
            Lastly, appropriate development of project implementation
            and follow-up capacity of financial institutions is an
            important objective of industrial development and requires
            serious attention during Bank supervision.
